title: Erdős Problem #958: Distance Multiplicities and Point Configurations
description: Is it true that k = n-1 distinct distances with multiplicities {n-1,...,1} characterizes equidistant points on a line or circle? NO - other configurations exist (Clemen-Dumitrescu-Liu, 2025).

overview.historicalContext: Erdős Problem #958 asks whether a special distance multiplicity pattern characterizes equidistant points on lines or circles. Erdős himself conjectured NO — other configurations should exist. Clemen, Dumitrescu, and Liu (2025) proved Erdős was right by finding arc-plus-center counterexamples.
overview.problemStatement: Let A ⊂ ℝ² be a finite set of size n with k distinct distances and multiplicity function f. Is it true that k = n-1 and {f(dᵢ)} = {n-1,...,1} if and only if A is equidistant on a line or circle? Answer: NO.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines Point, distanceSet, multiplicity, multiplicityMultiset. Standard configurations (isEquidistantLine, isEquidistantCircle, isStandardConfig) and the special pattern (hasSpecialPattern) are defined. The FALSE conjecture (OriginalConjecture) is stated. The counterexample (isArcPlusCenter) and Clemen-Dumitrescu-Liu theorem are axiomatized. The summary theorem combines both results.
keyInsights: Special pattern: k = n-1 distances with multiplicities {n-1, ..., 1}
Standard configurations (equidistant on line/circle) satisfy this pattern
Arc + center configuration also satisfies it — the conjecture is FALSE
Erdős correctly predicted other configurations exist
Clemen-Dumitrescu-Liu (2025) proved the disproof with arc+center counterexamples
The center has distance 1 to all arc points, giving the right multiplicity structure

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #958 is SOLVED. The conjectured characterization (special distance pattern ⟺ equidistant on line or circle) is FALSE. Clemen, Dumitrescu, and Liu (2025) found counterexamples: equidistant points on a short arc of a unit circle plus the center satisfy the pattern but are not standard configurations.
conclusion.implications: Understanding which distance patterns characterize point configurations. The special pattern alone does not uniquely determine configuration type. Arc + center is a new family of solutions that Erdős predicted would exist.
openQuestions: Are there other families of configurations with the special pattern?
What is the complete characterization of sets with this pattern?
Do similar results hold in higher dimensions?
What other distance patterns characterize specific configurations?
